pages.title: Our Story
pages.content:
Since 1985, La Dolce Vita has been a cornerstone of Italian dining in London. What began as a small family trattoria has blossomed into one of the city's most beloved restaurants.

Chef Marco Rossi

Born in Naples and trained in Rome's finest kitchens, Chef Marco brings 30 years of culinary passion to every dish. His philosophy is simple: let the ingredients speak for themselves.

"Cooking is not just about food — it's about memories, family, and sharing moments of joy around the table."

Our Philosophy

We believe great food starts with great ingredients. Every morning, our team selects the freshest produce from local markets. Our pasta is made by hand, daily. Our sauces simmer for hours. There are no shortcuts at La Dolce Vita.

Our Values

Passion

Every dish crafted with love and dedication

Freshness

Only the finest seasonal ingredients

Family

Every guest is part of our family
pages.excerpt: A family tradition of Italian excellence since 1985
pages.meta_description: Discover the story behind La Dolce Vita. From a small Naples family kitchen to one of London's finest Italian restaurants.

Menu items may change seasonally. Please inform us of any allergies or dietary requirements.

pages.title: Events
pages.content:
Join us for special evenings that celebrate the art of Italian living.

Every Thursday

Wine Tasting Evenings

Explore Italian wine regions with our sommelier. 5 wines, paired with artisan cheese and charcuterie. £45 per person.

Monthly — 1st Saturday

Cooking Masterclass

Learn to make fresh pasta from scratch with Chef Marco. Hands-on, fun, and delicious. £75 per person including lunch.

Available Daily

Private Dining

Our elegant private room seats up to 24 guests. Perfect for birthdays, anniversaries, and corporate dinners. Custom menus available.

Seasonal

Truffle Season Menu

November through February, experience our special truffle menu featuring fresh black and white truffles from Umbria. 5-course tasting menu £95.

articles.title: The Art of Handmade Pasta: Our Chef's Secret
articles.content:
Every morning at 6 AM, before the restaurant opens, Chef Marco begins his daily ritual. Flour mountains on a wooden board, eggs from our local farm, and hands that have shaped millions of pasta pieces over three decades.

"The secret isn't in a recipe," Marco says with a knowing smile. "It's in your hands. The dough tells you what it needs — you just have to listen."

The Process

Our pasta starts with 00 flour from a mill in Campania that has been grinding wheat for over 200 years. We mix it with free-range eggs from a farm in Kent. The dough rests for exactly 30 minutes — never more, never less.

Each shape has its purpose. Tagliatelle for our ragù — wide enough to hold the sauce. Pappardelle for wild boar. Ravioli for our ricotta and spinach filling. Every cut is made by hand.

Why It Matters

In a world of dried, factory-made pasta, we choose the harder path. Fresh pasta cooks in 3 minutes instead of 12. It absorbs sauce differently. It has a texture that no machine can replicate. Most importantly, it tastes of care.

Come early enough to lunch and you might catch Marco at work through the kitchen window. It's a show worth watching.
articles.excerpt: Every morning at 6 AM, Chef Marco begins his daily ritual of making fresh pasta by hand.
articles.meta_title: The Art of Handmade Pasta — La Dolce Vita Blog
articles.meta_description: Discover how Chef Marco crafts fresh pasta by hand every morning at La Dolce Vita.

articles.title: Wine Pairing Guide: From Antipasti to Dolci
articles.content:
Italian food and wine were born to be together. But with hundreds of grape varieties and regional traditions, choosing the right bottle can feel overwhelming. Here's our sommelier's guide to perfect pairings.

Starters

For light antipasti — bruschetta, carpaccio, fresh mozzarella — reach for a crisp Pinot Grigio or a young Vermentino. The acidity cuts through oils and cleanses the palate between bites.

Pasta & Risotto

Match the weight of the sauce, not the pasta shape. Tomato-based sauces love Chianti Classico — the Sangiovese grape echoes the tomato's acidity. Cream-based dishes? Try an oaked Chardonnay from Alto Adige.

Meat & Fish

Grilled fish wants nothing more than a cold Falanghina. For red meats and game, bring out the big guns: Barolo or Brunello di Montalcino. These wines need food to truly shine.

Dessert

End with a glass of Vin Santo alongside biscotti, or a chilled Moscato d'Asti with fruit desserts. The sweetness of the wine should match (never exceed) the sweetness of the dish.

Ask our sommelier for personal recommendations — every palate is different.
articles.excerpt: Our sommelier's guide to matching Italian wines with every course.
articles.meta_title: Wine Pairing Guide — La Dolce Vita Blog
articles.meta_description: Learn how to pair Italian wines perfectly with every course, from antipasti to dolci.

articles.title: Farm to Table: Meet Our Local Suppliers
articles.content:
Behind every great dish is a great supplier. At La Dolce Vita, we've built relationships with local farms and artisan producers who share our passion for quality.

Kent Free-Range Farm

Our eggs come from hens that roam freely across 50 acres of Kent countryside. The difference in colour, flavour, and richness is immediately apparent in our pasta and desserts.

Borough Market Greengrocers

Three mornings a week, our sous chef visits Borough Market at dawn. Seasonal vegetables, fresh herbs, and exotic ingredients that aren't available through commercial suppliers.

Campania Flour Mill

Our 00 flour travels directly from a 200-year-old mill near Naples. The wheat is stone-ground slowly to preserve nutrients and develop the complex flavour profile that makes our pasta special.

Why It Matters

Sourcing locally isn't just about flavour — it's about community. We're proud that our kitchen supports British farmers while honouring Italian traditions. When you eat at La Dolce Vita, you're supporting a network of passionate food artisans who believe, as we do, that every ingredient tells a story.
articles.excerpt: The passionate farmers and artisan producers behind our menu.
articles.meta_title: Farm to Table — La Dolce Vita Blog
articles.meta_description: Meet the local farmers and artisan producers who supply La Dolce Vita's kitchen.

articles.title: Hosting the Perfect Italian Dinner Party
articles.content:
An Italian dinner party isn't about perfection — it's about abundance, warmth, and making your guests feel like family. Here are Chef Marco's tips for hosting at home.

Keep It Simple

Choose 3–4 courses maximum: an antipasto platter, a primo (pasta), a secondo (main), and a dolce (dessert). Don't try to make everything from scratch — buy good bread, excellent cheese, and quality charcuterie.

Prep Ahead

The host should never be stuck in the kitchen. Make your ragù a day ahead — it tastes better anyway. Prepare dessert in the morning. Set the table early. The goal is to be at the table with your guests.

The Table Matters

Use mismatched plates if you have them — that's more Italian than a matching set. Candles always. Fresh flowers in a simple vase. A big bottle of olive oil on the table. Bread in a basket.

Wine Rules

Open the red wine an hour before guests arrive. Serve white and rosé cold. Don't stress about perfect pairings — just have enough for everyone. Italians don't overthink wine; they drink what they enjoy.

The Most Important Rule

Linger at the table. In Italy, dinner can last 3–4 hours. Put your phone away. Tell stories. Laugh. The food is important, but the company is everything.
articles.excerpt: Chef Marco's tips for hosting an unforgettable Italian dinner at home.
articles.meta_title: Hosting the Perfect Italian Dinner Party — La Dolce Vita Blog
articles.meta_description: Chef Marco shares his tips for hosting a memorable Italian dinner party at home.
